frame.name: Dynamism
frame.definition:
<def-root>A physical <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts energy at a level specified by the target. This frame covers both individual-level/static uses ("an INTENSE person") as well as stage-level/dynamic uses ("an INTENSE look"), although the individual-level meaning seems more basic.
<ex>Although an <t>energetic</t> and able <fex name="Exer">warrior</fex>, Charlemagne tended to direct battles rather than fight in person.</ex> <ex><fex name="Act">She dumped a mug on the bedside table</fex> with <fex name="Deg">such</fex> <t>vigor</t> that steaming coffee spashed out.</ex> <ex>Swing the racket with <t>dynamic</t> <fex name="For">force</fex>.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Exer">I</fex> felt <fex name="Deg">particularly</fex> <t>sluggish</t> <fex name="Pla">at work</fex> <fex name="Tim">that day</fex>.</ex> <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, and <fen>Force</fen> belong to a Core set. <ex></ex> This frame also covers several productive metaphor cases. In the first one, movement or change caused by a social entity is conveyed as energy exerted by a physical entity. 'Social' here encompasses entities that are economic, political, technological, historical, cultural, and intimate: <ex><fex name="Exer">The private sector</fex> is <fex name="Deg">so much more</fex> <t>dynamic</t>.</ex> <ex>Singh had been under <t>intense</t> <fex name="Exer">political pressure</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Exer">Economies</fex> are <fex name="Tim">still</fex> <t>sluggish</t>.</ex> Relatedly, the influential effect of an psychological entity is described in terms of energy exertion by a physical entity. 'Psychological' includes the intellectual, emotional, and creative: <ex><fex name="Exer">Sinead's</fex> <fex name="Dom">emotional</fex> <t>intensity</t> permeates every nuance of every lyric.</ex> <ex>He finds <fex name="Exer">the Poet Laureate's theory about Shakespeare</fex> to be <fex name="Deg">more</fex> <t>energetic</t> <fex name="Deg">than persuasive</fex>.</ex> Both metaphors appear to involve a third metaphor, which is the anthropomorphization of processes (see examples directly above) or inhuman entities (e.g. in nature): <ex>The <t>lazy</t> <fex name="Act">creak</fex> of sails</ex> <ex>The <t>energetic</t> <fex name="Exer">waves</fex></ex> <ex>A broad, <t>lethargic</t> <fex name="Exer">river</fex></ex>
Further, there is a metonymy wherein energy exerted by people carrying out an activity characterizes instead a central object or other component of the activity: <ex>Lucker plays <t>lazy</t> <fex name="Act">games</fex>.</ex> <ex>She thought the <t>lazy</t> <fex name="Exer">days</fex> in France would never end.</ex>
<ex></ex> Compare to: Level_of_force_exertion. </def-root>

FE.name: Action
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Action</fen> that exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
<ex>He was given a <t>vigorous</t> <fex name="Act">slap</fex> on the ear for his behavior.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Exerter
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Exerter</fen> which exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
<ex>More deadly and painful is the chemical weaponry of the camouflaged but <t>lethargic</t> <fex name="Exer">stonefish</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE describes the energy exertion of the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen>.
<ex>I admired her <fex name="Desc">incredible</fex> <t>stamina</t> throughout the marathon.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Degree</fen> to which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts an energy.
<ex>Uncle Dickie was <fex name="Deg">exceedingly</fex> <t>dynamic</t> in the play that evening.</ex> Where <fen>Degree</fen> is expressed by a comparative or superlative form of the target, the FE is marked on the target (as well as on the rest of the comparative/superlative expression, if present):
<ex>Uncle John gave a <fex name="Deg">much</fex> <t><fex name="Deg">lazier</fex></t> performance <fex name="Deg">than Unckle Dickie</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts an energy.
<ex>Charlie's workout was <t>intense</t> even <fex name="Tim">first thing in the morning</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Force
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Force</fen> that exerts an energy of the level specified by the target.
<ex> They were trying to harness some of the lightening's <t>intense</t> <fex name="For">power</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Circumstances</fen> under which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts an energy.
<ex>Athletes gradually release <t>energy</t> <fex name="Cir">in long-distance events</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location where the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts its energy. <ex>Because of the added space, our ultimate frisbee game was more <t>vigorous</t> <fex name="Pla">in Golden Gate Park</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Domain
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Domain</fen> is the field in which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> exerts its energy.
<ex>On the stage of New York's Felt Forum, Eddie Murphy glows with a <fex name="Dom">kinetic</fex> <t>dynamism</t> that captivates the audience.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: dynamic.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: characterized by energy or effective action; vigorously active or forceful

lexUnit.name: dynamism.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: great energy, force, or power; vigor

lexUnit.name: energetic.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: possessing or showing energy, esp. in abundance; vigorous

lexUnit.name: energy.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: available power or the exertion of such power

lexUnit.name: intense.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: existing at an extreme degree or exhibiting a high degree (ex. of strength)

lexUnit.name: intensity.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or condition of being intense

lexUnit.name: lazy.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: averse to work, activity, or exertion

lexUnit.name: laziness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or condition of being lazy

lexUnit.name: lethargic.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: relating to lethargy; drowsy, sluggish and/or apathetic

lexUnit.name: lethargy.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or state of being drowsy, unenergetic, and/or apathetic

lexUnit.name: sluggish.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: indisposed to action or exertion; unenergetic

lexUnit.name: sluggishness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or condition of being sluggish

lexUnit.name: stamina.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: strength of physical constitution; power to endure

lexUnit.name: vigor.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: active strength or force, or energetic activity
